newsitem.title: USA: Pakistan needs to take decisive measures - IMF.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan needs to take decisive measures - IMF.

text.p: Pakistan needs to take "decisive" measures to stabilize its economy, a senior International Monetary Fund official said on Thursday.
"There is a need for a decisive set of measures to be implemented by the government,' IMF First Deputy Managing Director Stanley Fischer told Reuters. "That is what we're looking for."

Fischer is flying to New York today to meet Pakistan Prime Minister Benazhir Bhutto to discuss what needs to be done and the possibility of the IMF sending a mission to the country to try to work out an economic plan with the government.

The IMF withheld an $80 million tranche due in June, and part of a $600 million standby loan, pending a review of Pakistan's 1996-97 budget. "We'll see whether the government can implement the polcies that are needed to stabilize the situation," Fischer said.
An adviser to Bhutto told the IMF/World Bank annual meeting on Wednesday that Pakistan was working to get back into the good graces of the two organizations.
Bhutto is also slated to meet World Bank President James Wolfensohn Thursday. Wolfensohn, who is flying to New York for the meeeting, termed the get-together a "courtesy call."
